column10: notes
column14: other International review board or metastudy link(s)

column10: Abatacept appears to reduce joint pain and improve function.

A number of systematic reviews of randomized controlled trials have concluded that agnus castus helps improve PMS symptoms, and is considered safe. However, one review does point to the need for high-quality trials comparing the size of the effect against other treatment options.
column11: Archives of Gynecology and Obstetrics; The European Menopause Journal, Archives of Women's Mental Health, American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Electronic Physician

column10: Ingestion of aloe vera is associated with diarrhea, electrolyte imbalance and kidney disfunction.
column11: Journal of Environmental Science and Health

column10: There is currently an absence of high quality clinical trial evidence to support the use of Aloe vera as treatment for wounds.
We found one study working with diabetes patients with high blood levels of fat (dyslipidemia). One 300mg capsule every 12 hours for 2 months has a significant positive impact on blood lipid levels.
While there is no evidence that andrographis is effective as a treatment, it can help to reduce the symptoms.
Evidence of anti-oxidants as treatment for male infertility is inconclusive.
Antixoxidants have no health benefits. In fact, beta carotene, vitamin A and vitamin E appear to increase the risk of death.

A review of 5 human trials concludes Ashwagandha reduces anxiety & stress. It does point out that the study methods were really varied though, making thorough cross-referencing of the results difficult. The review calls for more trials.
column11: The Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine

column10: In a single pilot study on 46 men with low-sperm count, ashwagandha supplementation appeared to increase sperm count by 167%, semen volume by 53%, & sperm motility by 57%.

A recent (2015) pilot study on 86 patients found that in combination with Sidh Makardhwaj (a mineral & herbal medicine), Ashwagandha reduced pain & inflammation. However, study limitations including 'small sample size, short duration, non randomization and lack of a control group' mean further studies are necessary.
Promising results in rats, but no human trials yet.
Astragalus stengthens the immune system, boosting resistance to infections. However, studies are limited.
Astagalus might have significant positive effects for patients with chronic kidney disease when combined with conventional treatments. However, the evidence is of low quality.

A study of high-dose benfotiamine (300 mg/day) supplementation over 24 months showed no significant effects upon peripheral nerve function or soluble markers of inflammation in patients with type 1 diabetes.
The findings are mixed, with some trials showing no effect and some showing some short-term benefits.

Compounds found in brewers' yeast and mushrooms. Most studies so far have been done in animals or test tubes, rather than on human subjects. It appears that beta-glucans inhibit tumor growth in mice. Trials on human subjects are needed.
Reduced number of colds by 25% and severity of symptoms by 15%. Might increase the body's ability to fend off infections.
There is not enough evidence to support using bitter melon in the treatment of diabetes.
There is insufficient evidence to claim that black cohosh improves menopause symptoms.
Reviews have found no association between black tea and ovarian or breast cancer risk.
Borage seed oil improves pain and function, and probably has no adverse effects.
Bromelain reduces arthritis symptoms. More research into dosage and adverse effects is required.
Butterbur extract may lower the frequency and severity of migraines.
Caffiene appears to slow cognitive decline and prevent Alzheimer's. But the results are not definitive.
Enhances consolidation of long term memories. Improves memory in young adults during their non-optimal time of day (mornings).
column11: Borota et al 2014, Frontiers in Psychology

column10: Epidemiological evidence shows women who consume more than three cups of coffee a day have a lower cancer risk than people who drink less than one cup per month.
High quality evidence has shown that extra calcium can slightly reduce blood pressure, especially in people younger than 35.
No evidence that calcium supplementation stops colorectal cancer itself, but it does inhibit potentially pre-cancerous colorectal polyps (adenomatous polyps)
Calcium might help to prevent fractures, although the results have been contradictory.

A review of eight studies including 30,970 participants found that calcium plus vitamin D supplementation reduced total fracture risk by 15% and hip fracture risk by 30%. Numerous sensitivity and subgroup analyses produced similar summary associations

column4: breast cancer in premenopausal women, cancer
column10: There is no firm evidence that calcium and vitamin D supplementation decreases cancer risk.

column4: nausea and vomiting due to chemotherapy
column10: Promising evidence showing a reduction in nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy. The FDA has approved 2 synthetic cannabis drugs for treating chemo-related nausea.

Definitely lowers eye pressure, but only temporarily (3-4hrs). Since Glaucoma is a long-term disease, a LOT of cannabis would be required to maintain low pressure levels. Also, cannabis might cause additional damage to the eye by restricting blood flow to the optic nerve.

2 studies involving a total of 790 subjects showed positive results. Improved muscle spasms, pain, sleep quality, and mobility. Cannabis drug Sativex is approved for use in MS patients in 30 countries.
Several good quality trials have shown cannabinoids to be modestly effective in treating chronic pain. The harms and side-effects may outweigh the benefits though. Larger and longer trials needed.
column11: British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology, Cochrane

column10: Capsaicin comes from chili peppers. Evidence has found that inhaling 4 micrograms at least 5 times a day can reduce inflammation, but the quality of the evidence is low.
Promising results in mice and in vitro, but no human trials yet.
No human trials.
No high-quality human trials.

Chemicals known as flavanols, found in cocoa products, are thought to widen blood vessels and cause a minor drop in blood pressure. Further trials are needed to ascertain long-term efficacy. Does not apply to mllk chocolate.
Chromium might lower blood glucose levels. It might also help with fat loss, which could benefit those with diabetes.
Cinnamon is no more effective than placebo in controlling glucose levels.
30ml of coconut oil per day might help to reduce waist size, possibly because the fat in coconut oil isn't easily stored.
A metastudy found that the more coffee a person drinks, the lower their risk of cardiovascular disease. The optimum amount of coffee for this benefit was 3-5 per day.
A large study of over 650,000 people found that coffee drinking reduced all cause mortality, whether it was instant, ground, or decaffeinated.
A few small human studies suggest possible effects on Alzheimers.
column11: The Journal of Nutritional Health and Aging

column10: CoQ10 improves insulin secretion in those with type 2 diabetes. However, human trials have been tiny.
Some tentative evidence that CoQ10 might affect migraine sensitivity. But much more research needed.
Pooled data from two trials showed that coenzyme Q10 did not affect blood pressure compared to placebo.'
There is no statistically significant evidence that cranberry juice or supplements prevent UTIs.
Creatine doesn't have a significant effect in those with normal brain function, but it can benefit those with impaired brain function when combined with CoQ10.
Dandelion might have antimicrobial properties, which could help with throat infections.
Devil's Claw extract can reduce lower back pain by blocking the pathways that cause joint inflammation.
DHEA has no beneficial impact on body composition, performance etc.
DHEA might improve memory in young men.
Long term safety data is non-existent. May increase risk of cancer.
Echinacea might have a slight impact on preventing and treating colds, but the results are statistically insignificant.
Egg shell membrane eases joints by increasing cell production and decreasing inflammation. 500mg a day gives rapid results.

Several in vitro studies together with two exploratory studies in humans and one open study in chimpanzees indicate that the aqueous elderberry extract Sambucol may be useful for the treatment of viral influenza infections. These promising effects of elderberry fruit preparations from experimental and clinical studies should be backed by more rigorous studies before these preparations are recommended in the prevention of diseases and in treatment schedules.
Evening primrose oil is no more effective than placebo.
column11: Journal of Psychosomatic Obstetrics and Gynecology

column9: fish oil omega 3 low sperm count
column10: Feverfew reduces migraine frequency by just over half a migraine a month.
In the largest and longest study of its kind, researchers found that fish oil/omega 3 had no statistically significant impact on cognitive decline.
column11: The Journal of the American Medical Association

column10: Eating more fish has been recommended as one way of possibly reducing asthma. Populations (such as Eskimo communities) with diets high in fish also have low rates of asthma. As diets in other communities have become higher in saturated fats, asthma has also increased. The theory has been that an ingredient in fish oil may reduce inflammation. Inflammation causes the swelling in the airways of the lungs that leads to asthma attacks. However, this review of trials found that people with asthma changing their diets to include more fish oil did not improve their asthma.
Fish oil can counter chemotherpay-related damage to white blood cells.
Fish oil supplementation has a very minor positive impact on some measures of learning and performance.
It is thought that omega 3 reduces the risk of colorectal cancer and is effective in its treatment.
Omega 3 probably has no beneficial effect for those with Crohn's Disease.
There may be some benefit to people with cystic fibrosis taking regular omega-3 supplements, but larger, longer studies are needed for confirmation.
A small study of 211 men it was found that omega 3 supplementation significantly increased sperm count.
Omega 3 probably has no beneficial effect for those with type 2 diabetes.
Recent studies have linked fish oil intake with increased prostate cancer risk.
column11: Journal of the National Cancer Institutue.

column10: In one study, supplementation delayed the onset of psychosis in those on track to develop certain mental health conditions.

Our primary analyses suggest a small-to-modest, non-clinically beneficial effect of n-3PUFAs on depressive symptomology compared to placebo; however the estimate is imprecise, and we judged the quality of the evidence on which this result is based to be low/very low.'

Two large (10,000+) open-label trials found that 1g or more of omega-3 fatty acids per day gave significant protection against coronary events. However, subsequent placebo-controlled trials did not. The authors conclude that, overall, the hypothesis that omega-3 supplements protect the heart in various ways is plausible & supported by numerous studies, but more research is needed.
column11: New England Journal of Medicine, JAMA Cardiology, Cochrane

column10: A meta-analysis concluded that preterm birth & early preterm birth were reduced in women receiving omega-3. Most of the important studies assessed were of high or moderate quality, & more studies to establish causality of omega-3 in relation to pre-term birth are not needed.
Population studies indicate a slight possibility flaxeed could reduce breast cancer tumour growth. No controlled trials have been carried out.
Folic acid helps to prevent birth defects, but timing of supplementation is important.
When combined with vitamin B12 can be associated with increased cancer risk.

Collectively, the literature reveals preclinical and clinical evidence for various phytomedicines modulating GABA-pathways, with comparative anxiolytic effect to the current array of pharmaceuticals, along with good safety and tolerability profiles
Garlic might reduce blood pressure, but further research is required.

Although there were inconsistent evidence from human studies, results of the animal and laboratory results were mostly consistent. The overall findings may suggest that intakes of aged garlic are inversely associated with cancer. Overall, the current findings are not sufficient to assess the effects of aged garlic on cancer. However, due to anticancer properties of aged garlic, its consumption along with healthy diet may have beneficial effects on cancer. More clinical trials and prospective cohort human studies with adequate sample size are necessary.
Garlic might prevent certain cancers, but there is a lack of clinical trial evidence. The WHO recommends consuming at least one clove a day for general health benefits.
There is insufficient clinical trial evidence regarding the effects of garlic in preventing or treating the common cold.
column11: Cochrane: Garlic for the common cold

column10: Ginger prevents nausea and vomitting for some people in certain circumstances.
There is insufficient clinical trial evidence for the use of ginkgo bilboa as a treatment for dementia.
column11: University of Oxford Medical Sciences Division

column10: There is no convincing evidence for ginseng enhancing cognition in healthy people, and only low quality evidence that it helps dementia patients.
Studies using a specific brand of glucosamine (Rotta) found that patients' pain decreased. However, studies using other brands found no difference between glucosamine and placebo.
There is insufficient evidence to determine whether glutamine supplements are beneficial or harmful.
The available trial data do not provide evidence that glutamine supplementation confers important benefits for preterm infants.'
Supplementation for 90 days appeared to show some improvements in eye-health for seniors. But more research is needed.
Grape seed extract is being investigated for possible effect on wound healing. But no reliable or substantial studies have been carried out.
The evidence is conflicting. However, drinking 3-5 cups a day might have general health benefits.
Drinking green tea might help to reduce total cholesterol levels, but trials were small and exposed to bias.

column9: horse chestnut seed extract chronic venous insufficiency
column10: Horse chestnut seed extract is effective in treating CVI. However, further research is needed.
Injected hyaluronic acid might have a small effect in the treatment of osteoarthritis. However, the trials are biased and the results questionable.
Iron supplementation in infants might benefit their psychomotor development, but not their mental or behavioural development.
Iron and folate supplementation reduces iron deficiency anaemia for pregnant women. The impact on babies is less clear.
Kava might have a small but significant effect on anxiety, but more information is required about the safety of long-term use.
One study showed 300mg a day reduced inflammation and soothed arthritis symptoms after 7 days.
Krill oil significantly reduced both emotional and physical PMS symptoms in one study.
One study found that L-arginine had a significant beneficial impact on exercise performance. However, the trial was tiny.
L-cartinine may alleviate pain in patients with diabetic nerve issues (neuropathy).
There is no evidence that lysine has a preventative effect on cold sores.
Lavender is effective in treating mild to moderate depression, especially when combined with the antidepressant imipramine.
One small study found inhaling lavender before bed relieves sleepiness on waking in healthy adults, but the trial was tiny.
One study found drinking leucine solution while exercising speeds up recovery, but the trial was tiny.
A combination of Chinese herbs lingzhi and san miao san may reduce pain, but does not provide any other significant benefits (e.g. antiinflammatory).
Taking lutein alone (or combined with zeaxanthin) may have little or no effect on progression to late AMD and vision loss (low-certainty evidence).'
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of lycopene in preventing prostate cancer.
Low levels of magnesium in the diet are linked to high blood pressure and cholesterol. Magnesium treatment might be effective as a preventative.
Children with ADHD tend to have low magnesium and vitamin B6 levels. It's unclear whether supplementation reduces the symptoms of ADHD.
Melatonin can help to regulate the body-clock and improve sleep. However, it does not affect all groups of people in the same way, and the evidence is low quality.
Milk thistle might be beneficial in treating hepatitis and other liver diseases, and protecting the liver from the impact of diabetes. However, the trials were low quality.
MSM supplementation is associated with slight reduction in pain and improvement in function, but the results may not be clinically significant.

Evidence from four [low quality] trials of antenatal dietary supplementation with myo-inositol during pregnancy shows a potential benefit for reducing the incidence of gestational diabetes...Further trials for this promising antenatal intervention for preventing gestational diabetes are encouraged.'

Problems with glutamate function in the brain are thought to affect addiction and compulsive behaviour. NAC might improve glutamate function, which could possibly help in the control of addictions and compulsive disorders.
Nettles might be effective in treating urinary issues in men by reducing inflammation. But we could find no recent studies.
Although Niacin has long been thought an effective treatment for heart disease, recent findings show that it does not help, and can have severe adverse effects.
column11: The New England Journal of Medicine.

column9: olive leaf extract blood pressure cholesterol
column10: One study found that olive leaf extract has beneficial effects on vascular health, although the trial was small.
There is insufficient evidence to suggest omega 3 has any beneficial effect on children with ADHD.
There is insufficient evidence to claim that omega 3 has any impact on heart health, either in healthy people or those with cardiovascular disease.
One study found that omega 6 prevented tumours from growing, but this was a cell study, i.e. not tested on humans.
column11: Journal of the National Cancer Institute

column10: Standard medical advice has been to substitute 'bad fats' with 'good fats' for heart health. However, omega 6, a 'good fat', has been found to have no benefit on heart health.
Highly toxic. If used at all, should be used with extreme caution.
Peppermint oil relaxes muscles, which relieves IBS-related muscle spasms. Peppermint oil might be more effective than conventional anti-spasmodics and fibre treatment.
The evidence does not support the use of piracetam as a treatment for cognitive impairment.
Medication that prevents potassium loss has no significant impact on blood pressure at low doses. Trials at high doses are unavailable.
The evidence for probiotics as cholesterol-lowering is conflicting and results are unclear.
A particular probiotic (B. infantis 35624) improves IBS symptoms such as pain, bloating, and bowel movement difficulty. Evidence for other types of probiotic is limited.
No significant evidence that probiotics are any more effective than placebo in treating UTIs, but can't be ruled out since data quality is poor.

Based on this systematic review and meta-analysis of 31 randomized controlled trials including 8672 patients, moderate certainty evidence suggests that probiotics are effective for preventing [diarrhea associated with antibiotic use]...The short-term use of probiotics appears to be safe and effective when used along with antibiotics in patients who are not immunocompromised or severely debilitated.'

Very low quality evidence suggests probiotics might get rid of vulvovaginal candida in non-pregnant women more quickly than conventional treatments, and may prevent it coming back on a short term basis. High quality trials are needed.
A small study found quercetin has no significant impact on athletic performance.
column11: International Journal of Sport Nutrition and Exercise Metabolism

column10: The meta-analysis results showed that patients who had been given G. lucidum alongside with chemo/radiotherapy were more likely to respond positively compared to chemo/radiotherapy alone. G. lucidum treatment alone did not demonstrate the same regression rate as that seen in combined therapy.' However, studies reviewed were small and there were some quality concerns.
No human trials as yet.
Some preliminary evidence that resveratrol can play a role in modulating diabetes symptoms.
Resveratrol has cardioprotective benefits, although scientists don't know quite how it works.
Rhodiola rosea L. is effective in treating fatigue. However, the quality of the trials conducted is questionable.

In conclusion, saffron may exert antidepressant effects comparable to those of pharmaceutical antidepressants such as fluoxetine, citalopram, and imipramine, with possibly fewer observed side effects. Further studies are needed to clarify exact mechanisms responsible for antidepressant-like effects of this spice.'
column11: Journal of Affective Disorders, Phytomedicine, Journal of Ethnopharmacology, Journal of Integrative Medicine, Human Psychopharmacology

column10: A review of eight studies showed no strong evidence of the effectiveness of SAM-e when taken on its own. More study needed.
There is no evidence that saw palmetto at any dosage improves urinary-tract-related problems.
There is insufficient evidence to suggest selenium lowers cancer risk.
Silicic acid might help to prevent Alzheimer's Disease by decreasing the amount of aluminium in the body. We await more research.
No clinical evidence has been found for the efficacy of slippery elm in treating sore throats.
Very preliminary evidence shows Spirulina reducing blood pressure and lower lipids.
St John's Wort performs better than a placebo in improving depression symptoms, and not significantly different to antidepressants, which had more side-effects.
Daily treatment with St. John's wort had no effect on the emotional and physical symptoms of PMS.
No human trials.
TMG appears to have no significant effect on metabolism in humans.
Tryptophan and 5-HTP might alleviate depression, but the studies conducted are unreliable, and the safety of the substances is questionable.
Turmeric might have anti-cancer effects, particularly on colon and pancreatic cancer, cervical neoplasia and Barrets metaplasia.
A high quality, long-term (18 months), but small study (40 subjects) found that 90mg of curcumin twice daily improved memory in adults without dementia.
Tumeric may be an effective therapy for peptic ulcers and ulcerative colitis when combined with conventional medications. However, larger trials are needed.

Curcumin appears to be safe, well-tolerated, and efficacious among depressed patients. More robust randomized controlled trials with larger sample sizes and follow-up studies carried out over a longer duration should be planned to ascertain its benefits. However, Curcumin has poor bioavailability. 9-20 teaspoons daily would be required to get the desired effect.
column11: Journal of the American Medical Directors Association, Journal of Affective Disorders, Phytotherapy Research, European Neuropsychopharmacology, Journal of Clinical Pharmacology,

column10: The evidence suggests that tyrosine intake improves working memory and information processing in healthy adults under strain.
Tyrosine may help with mental health problems by maintaining neurotransmitters, which affect mood.
One study found no difference between valerian and placebo in the treatment of anxiety. Research using larger samples is required.
No significant differences between valerian and placebo in the treatment of insomnia. Valerian might have a number of adverse side effects.

Data on the effect of vitamin A supplementation for the prevention of death [in children 0.5-5yrs] were available from 19 of the included studies, and the combined results indicate that vitamin A reduces overall risk of death and death due to diarrhoea by 12%. Vitamin A does not specifically reduce death due to measles, respiratory infections, or meningitis, but it can reduce new occurrences of diarrhoea and measles.'
There is no evidence that beta-carotene prevents cancer.
It appears that high doses of retinol (10,000 ID/d+) can cause birth defects in human and animal infants.
Vitamin B treatment slows brain shrinkage and significantly reduces brain cell death.
column11: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

column10: A review of 18 studies found that vitamin B reduced psychiatric symptoms significantly more than in a control group.
Vitamin B2 (also known as Riboflavin) may reduce the frequency of migraines.

For high-risk patients, we are recommending that nicotinamide be considered now as a chemoprevention option together with ongoing sunscreen use and regular skin checks. Further studies in lower-risk individuals are needed before it is considered for the broader population.'
column11: International Journal of Cancer, Photodermatology, Photoimmunology & Photomedicine, CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians, New England Journal of Medicine

column10: The evidence for vitamin B8 (also known as Inositol) as a treatment for depression is unclear.
Several small studies have found that vitamin B8 seems to work as effectively as conventional medication in the treatment of anxiety-related disorders, but more research is needed.

Vitamin C supplementation does not reduce the incidence of colds in the general population, although it can shorten their duration. For those under extreme physical stress (e.g. marathon runners) vitamin C appears to half the risk of developing a cold.
It appears that supplementation for with vitamin D deficiency increases bone density and helps to prevent fractures.
Low levels of vitamin D in the body are associated with depression, but whether or not vitamin D deficiency actually causes depression is uncertain.
The association between vitamin D status and diabetes is unclear.
In one trial, 10.8% of children taking vitamin D(3) contracted influenza, compared with 18.6% of children in the placebo group. It also reduced the number of flu-related asthma attacks.

A review suggests that vitamin D3 may reduce mortality, showing that about 150 participants need to be treated over five years for one additional life to be saved. It found some evidence that vitamin D3 seems to decrease mortality in elderly people not dependent on help or living in institutional care.
One of the largest & most rigorous trials ever conducted (over 83,000 participants) found that vitamin D supplementation did not result in lower incidence of cardiovascular events.
column11: JAMA, New England Journal of Medicine

column10: One of the largest & most rigorous trials ever conducted (25,871 participants over 5 years) found that vitamin D supplementation did not result in lower incidence of invasive cancers.
column11: PubMed, New England Journal of Medicine

column10: Vitamin D has been found to offer some protection against severe asthma attacks in adults with mild to moderate asthma. Further trials focusing on children and people who experience frequent severe asthma attacks are needed before definitive clinical recommendations can be made.'
High dosages of vitamin E might increase all-cause mortality. Small amounts can be beneficial, but the line between helpful and dangerous is unclear at this stage.

We found no evidence that...vitamin E given to people with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) prevents progression to dementia, or that it improves cognitive function in people with MCI or dementia due to Alzheimer's disease (AD). However, there is moderate quality evidence from a single study that it may slow functional decline in AD.'

The very limited results of this review highlight the lack of evidence currently available to determine the effectiveness of vitamin K supplementation for the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease, and demonstrate the need for further high quality trials in this area.'
Vitamin K2 has repeatedly been shown to improve bone strength, particularly in post-menopausal women.

It can be speculated that Vit K and its derivatives and analogs may become potential compounds for future development of anticancer therapy. However, extensive preclinical and clinical trials are yet required to elucidate the full spectrum of anticancer effects of VK, either alone or in synergistic combination with other standard drugs, to validate its usefulness as a potent anticancer agent.
column11: American Journal of Clinical Nutrition, OncoTarget

column10: Three studies, covering 160,000 people, found that the risk of type II diabetes was 21-27% lower among those who ate the most wholegrains than among those who ate the least.
column11: Proceedings of the Nutrition SocietyNutrition Research Reviews

column10: Xylitol, otherwise known as birch sugar, was found to reduce middle ear infections in otherwise healthy children by 8% (from 30% to 22%). It was administered via chewing gum, lozenges or syrup. Other studies have had similar positive results.
There is some evidence that xylitol in toothpaste might reduce tooth decay by 13% over 3 years. The studies have been of low quality, though.

A meta-analysis showed that oral zinc formulations may shorten the duration of symptoms of the common cold. However, large high-quality trials are needed before definitive recommendations for clinical practice can be made. Adverse effects were common and should be the point of future study.
Zinc supplementation in children is associated with a reduction in the incidence and prevalence of pneumonia.
